acknowledgments:
The Corporate Learning Branch would like to acknowledge the support we received from many of our colleagues and partners in multiple branches/ministries during the development of this learning resource. We also appreciate the invaluable comments we received during our engagement sessions.

In particular, our sincere thanks go out to colleagues and partners at the following entities:

* Policy & Legislation, BC Data Service, CITZ
* Multiculturalism & Anti-Racism Branch, AG
* PSA REDI, Policy and Employee Relations
* SDPR Inclusion, Diversity and Cultural Safety (IDCS) & Anti-Racism 101 course
* BIPOC Employee Resource Group
* Indigenous Employees Network
contentWarning:
> "Not everything that is faced can be changed, but nothing can be changed until it is faced." — James Baldwin

This learning pathway deals with sensitive topics. It touches on racism, inequity, power structures and the inherent imbalances that exist in our society, culture, and organizations.

The content of this pathway is primarily tailored for those new to the subject area. We, however, recognize that thousands of BC Public Service employees who represent the Black, Indigenous, and People of Color (BIPOC) and other marginalized communities are also completing this learning and may have a different baseline of knowledge and lived experience.

Irrespective of your life experiences, be prepared for moments when you will feel uncomfortable. Know that discomfort is normal and is often a prerequisite for positive change and growth. When you feel discomfort, it's not a sign that something is wrong — it's a sign that you are doing something right.

Some learners may find the training overwhelming due to personal experiences with racism and other forms of discrimination. In such circumstances, we encourage you to step back, prioritize emotional health, and return to the content.

As employees, you have access to [Employee and Family Assistance Services](https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/careers-myhr/all-employees/health-safety-and-sick-leave-resources/health/efas?keyword=EFAS) anytime you need. You will also find resources and other workplace support mechanisms related to anti-racism within module four and five of these pathways.

Canadians in crisis can also call or text 9-8-8 24/7 to access bilingual, trauma-informed, and culturally appropriate mental health, and suicide prevention support.

Let's dive into the learning journey with open minds and hearts as we strive to make BC Public Service an equitable, inclusive, and anti-racist organization.

In the words of Maya Angelou, **"Do the best you can until you know better. Then when you know better, do better."** This learning pathway is designed with that learning spirit in mind.
description: Learners have a better understanding of what it means to be “anti-racist” and what role they have within the BC Public Service in improving their capacities to respond to discrimination and racism at work. Publish test.
name: Anti-Racism in the BC Public Service 2

bookmarks.description: Key Definitions for Anti-Racism in the BCPS
bookmarks.title: Key Definitions | Anti-Racism in the BCPS - Learning Curator Pathway Aid

bookmarks.description: In this extract from his 2019 book How To Be an Antiracist, historian Ibram X. Kendi breaks down exactly what the term means – and why clear language is a vital first step in the battle against prejudice.
bookmarks.title: Ibram X. Kendi defines what it means to be an antiracist

bookmarks.description: Introduction to Unlearning & Undoing White Supremacy and Racism in the Office of the Provincial Health Officer
bookmarks.title: Introduction to Unlearning & Undoing White Supremacy and Racism in the Office of the Provincial Health Officer - Province of British Columbia

bookmarks.description: Anti-China sentiments — and political posturing — have led to racism against Asian Canadians.
bookmarks.title: White Supremacy in ‘British’ Columbia, and the China Syndrome | The Tyee

bookmarks.description: This website describes white supremacy culture as a framework for understanding racism. It allows us to explore the power structure and its imbalances in society.
bookmarks.title: What is White Supremacy Culture?

bookmarks.description: In this talk, Robin DiAngelo explains how racism is at play in white people and how to bring awareness to our condition and own racism to make a change and stop living a segregated life.
bookmarks.title: Nice Racism & White Fragility with Robin DiAngelo - YouTube

bookmarks.description: This New York times article introduces readers to the history of critical race theory in conceptualizing a framework needed in anti-racism studies.
bookmarks.title: What Is Critical Race Theory? A Brief History Explained - The New York Times

bookmarks.description: This CCDI-developed comprehensive glossary of terms provides a reference for terminology used within the Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion (EDI) and Accessibility learning space.
bookmarks.title: Canadian Centre for Diversity and Inclusion (CCDI) Glossary of Terms

bookmarks.description: In this interview, Professor Ibram X. Kendi discusses how being “anti-racist” differs from being “not racist.”
bookmarks.title: The difference between being "not racist" and antiracist | Ibram X. Kendi - YouTube

bookmarks.description: Glossary of Terms The Canadian Race Relations Foundation maintains a glossary with definitions of key concepts relevant to race relations, the promotion of Canadian identity, belonging and the mutuality of citizenship rights and responsibilities. About the glossary This list includes many of the terms commonly used in anti-racism and equity discourse today. They are gleaned […]
bookmarks.title: Glossary of Terms – Canadian Race Relations Foundation

steps.name: Contextualize Racism and Anti-Racism
steps.objective: Understand the context in which racism exists. Learn about anti-racism and why simply being “not racist” isn't enough.

bookmarks.description: A history of racism in British Columbia.
bookmarks.title: Challenging Racist British Columbia

bookmarks.description: Indigenous, Chinese, Japanese, Punjabi, Black, and European stories are woven together to present an astute look at the complicated histories that shaped BC as we know it today.
bookmarks.title: British Columbia: An Untold History | Knowledge.ca

bookmarks.description: Canada is usually referred to as a country of immigration, a country open to difference, a country that embraces multiculturalism. But more and more voices are rising to denounce ordinary or systemic racism and racist incidents, some of them tragic.
bookmarks.title: Racism in Canada: Words to tell wrongs | Radio-Canada.ca

steps.name: History of Racism in Canada
steps.objective: Learn about the history of racism in Canada to better understand the current context. "Contemporary racial oppression still has deeply connected roots in past racial oppression” and our societies operate within a racial frame that centers whiteness (Elias & Feagin, 2020, p. 21).

bookmarks.description: To the uninitiated, Canada may have a reputation for friendly and folksy charm. For Black and Indigenous peoples of the 'Great White North,' this veneer beli...
bookmarks.title: Yes—Canada has anti-Black racism, too - YouTube

bookmarks.description:
From hate to hope
Inquiry into hate in the COVID-19 pandemic
In August 2021, B.C.’s Human Rights Commissioner launched an inquiry into the rise of hate in B.C. during the COVID-19 pandemic. In March 2023, the Commissioner released her findings and recommendations.

Illustrations by Paige Jung
bookmarks.title: From hate to hope | BC's Office of the Human Rights Commissioner

bookmarks.description: Rampant Islamophobia is costing Canadian Muslims their peace of mind, their physical well-being and even their lives.
bookmarks.title: Combatting Hate: Islamophobia and its impact on Muslims in Canada

bookmarks.description: Participate in the investigation into Indigenous-specific discrimination in the health system in BC.
bookmarks.title: Addressing Racism in BC Health Care

bookmarks.description: This Montreal Holocaust Museum report uncovers the history of Antisemitism that greatly affects the Jewish community in Canada.
bookmarks.title: Brief History of Antisemitism in Canada

steps.name: Colours of Racism in Canada
steps.objective: Understand the different types of racism and discrimination that Indigenous, Black, and other racialized and marginalized people experience in the Canadian context.

bookmarks.description: The Human Rights Code helps protect people against discrimination in B.C. based on parts of their identity.
bookmarks.title: Human rights in B.C. | BC's Office of the Human Rights Commissioner

bookmarks.description: On May 2, 2022, we introduced the Anti-Racism Data Act. Its one of the first pieces of legislation to be co-developed with Indigenous Peoples under the Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples Act.
bookmarks.title: The Anti-Racism Data Act -

bookmarks.description: The Action Plan outlines goals and outcomes for ending Indigenous-specific racism and discrimination in British Columbia.
bookmarks.title: Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples Act Action Plan

bookmarks.description: The purpose of this policy is to promote safe, healthy BC Public Service workplaces, free from discrimination, bullying and harassment. This policy covers individual behaviours and accountability. The BC Public Service, in cooperation with its unions and associations, is committed to promoting respectful behaviour. Respectful behaviour reflects BC Public Service corporate ethics and values, supports diversity and inclusion and promotes positive communication and collaborative working relationships – all essential to fostering public trust and confidence in the BC Public Service.
bookmarks.title: HR Policy 11 – Discrimination, Bullying and Harassment in the Workplace

bookmarks.description: This policy statement applies to all persons and organizations covered by the Public Service Act. The policy statement supports the core policy objective that “public service employees exhibit the highest standards of conduct.”
bookmarks.title: HR Policy 09 – Standards of Conduct for BC Public Service Employees

bookmarks.description: The BC Public Service is an inclusive employer representative of the people of British Columbia. Everyone belongs. This page outlines Where We All Belong, the three-year diversity and inclusion strategy for the BC Public Service.
bookmarks.title: Equity, Diversity & Inclusion Strategy for the BC Public Service - Province of British Columbia

bookmarks.description: The corporate HR plan sets the strategic vision and guiding direction for the BC Public Service.
bookmarks.title: 2023 Corporate HR Plan

bookmarks.description: How to address a workplace conflict
bookmarks.title: Address a respectful workplace issue - Province of British Columbia

bookmarks.checkError: Could not verify directly but URL appears valid
bookmarks.description: Among others, section 15 of the Charter of Rights addresses our right to be free from discrimination based on race, national or ethnic origin, colour, religion, sex, age and mental or physical disability.
bookmarks.title: Charter of Rights and Freedoms

bookmarks.checkError: Could not verify directly but URL appears valid
bookmarks.description: This Report examines the development of anti-racism legislation in three Canadian provinces and underscores the existing Pan-Canadian gaps.
bookmarks.title: A Progress Report on Anti-Racism Policy Across Canada

steps.name: Existing Legislation, Policies and Strategies
steps.objective: This module emphasizes on the relevant legislations and policies available in British Columbia.

bookmarks.description: The BC General Employees Union (BCGEU) webpage also has various resources on anti-racism for membership.
bookmarks.title: BCGEU Anti-Racism Resources

bookmarks.description: Becoming Anti-Racist Infographic describes the different zones an individual progresses through on their journey to being Anti-Racist.
bookmarks.title: Anti-Racist "Zones" Infographic

bookmarks.description: This opinion piece presents three critical elements for creating a roadmap that helps individuals learn how to be actively anti-racist.
bookmarks.title: What You Can Do to Create an Anti-Racist Organization

bookmarks.checkError: Could not verify directly but URL appears valid
bookmarks.description: Resilience BCs Anti-Racism Network provides tools to help you make a future free of racism and hate a reality.
bookmarks.title: Resilience BC

bookmarks.description: The toolkit was created by BCs Office of the Human Rights Commissioner (BCOHRC) to help employers learn how to improve employment equity within their businesses and organizations.
bookmarks.title: Anti-discrimination policies and addressing complaints

steps.name: Becoming Anti-Racist in BC Public Service
steps.objective: This step outlines ways we can become anti-racist in our organization.
